The fact that you're asking this question makes you seem lazy, and is that really the impression you want to give to a potential recruiter/employer? You decide.

-----------
The answer above mine seems mean. This is a perfectly reasonable question! Not dumb or lazy at all!
I would recommend you do this.
Make a general cover letter for the kind of role you're interested (for example, software engineering) and leave blanks for the company names. Then it's just easy to copy and paste the company name into theprefilled cover letter and send that. 
Another resource you have is the career center  https://career.berkeley.edu/
They both have drop in advising and appointments! They can go over your resume, cover letter, and answer any and all questions about the internship search! Angie Luo https://career.berkeley.edu/staff-profiles#counseling
Was especially helpful for my software engineering internship specific questions.
Best of luck in your internship search! 
---------
Many companies actually share you sentiment. They don't like reading cover letters since it often doesn't tell them anything different from your resume. For example, Google recommends you don't submit a cover letter when applying to their positions. 

________

Cover letters are meant to allow you to speak directly to why you are a good fit for a specific position. They are different than your resume in the sense that they let you address specifically how your skills and experience pertain to the position itself. Look up cover letter examples to get an idea of how they tend to be written. Cover letters generally are only relevant when you want to apply to specialized positions. The reason I bring this up is that you are probably applying to new grad software engineering positions (I'm just assuming based on how this is EECS 101 piazza) which tend to not be very specialized positions. If this is the case it is likely unnecessary to write a cover letter. I would say however if you were applying to what you consider to be a specialized position then you should write a cover letter. In the future you will likely specialize more and for future jobs it is likely a cover letter will be important. If they ask why you want to work at the company and it seems like they only want a few sentences I would write something. That won't take too long and companies do really like to see that you are specifically interested in them. The suggestion the person above had about going to the career center is really good, the people there are really great. Also the first answer is mean and unhelpful and I don't like it when people are mean and unhelpful to people who are genuinely looking for advice. Why would anyone do that? This is a good, common question. 
----
I haven't written a lot of cover letters, but I've found that it's helpful to write them when you're applying for roles that aren't typical for your major/background/experience. i.e. if I'm a CS major and I apply to a computational bio company, I might want to specify in my cover letter how my background is applicable and why I'm interested. Also, don't worry about the first answer. You're honestly probably in the majority when it comes to wanting to write cover letters.

The fact that you're asking this question makes you seem lazy, and is that really the impression you want to give to a potential recruiter/employer? You decide.

Sorry if this is a dumb question. When I apply to internship, some companies as for a cover letter or "Why do you want to work for xxx?" Since I am applying to many companies, I didn't want to write any of these optional writing. However, how important are they? Should I invest my time in writing them?

Thanks!
